item.title: Covid-19: Crucial for pinged people to self-isolate - No 10
item.description: Downing Street tries to clear up confusion after a minister says people can make an "informed decision".

item.title: Jeff Bezos launches to space aboard New Shepard rocket ship
item.description: The world's richest man and three other passengers return safely just 11 minutes after take-off.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: I discussed ousting PM after 2019 election landslide
item.description: Boris Johnson's former aide says Downing Street rifts developed within days of a landslide victory.

item.title: Vaccine proof plans considered for some sports events
item.description: Fans may be required to show proof of full vaccination to attend sports venues with capacities of about 20,000 or more by the end of September.

item.title: Extreme heat warnings for UK to last until Friday
item.description: People have been warned about sunburn and heat exhaustion, with Heathrow seeing its hottest day of the year.

item.title: Nike trainer output at key factory hit by Covid outbreak
item.description: Nike could run out of its Vietnamese-made trainers because of a rise in Covid infections in the region.

item.title: Women's state pension: Compensation closer for Waspi campaigners
item.description: The government was too slow to tell women they would be directly affected by the rising state pension age.

item.title: Eid al-Adha prayers continue as rockets fired in Afghanistan
item.description: Some of the worshippers in Kabul appeared frightened and unsure what to do when they heard multiple explosions.

item.title: Record 430 migrants cross English Channel in single day
item.description: Some 50 people, including women and young children, were seen landing on a Kent beach in a dinghy.

item.title: Vue cinema chain fined Â£750,000 over seat crush death
item.description: Ateeq Rafiq died after getting his head stuck under a motorised footrest while searching for keys.

item.title: Almost a quarter of England's pupils out of school
item.description: The "pingdemic" continues to affect schools and families with nearly 25% absent as the term ends.

item.title: Man stuck in M4 jam plays football on carriageway
item.description: There was a three-hour tailback on the M4 in Wiltshire after a lorry caught fire.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Athletes find new ways to train in lockdown
item.description: Participants in the upcoming Games have been going to unusual lengths to stay in shape under restrictions.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: The hijabi referee making Olympic history
item.description: The first Arab and African woman to referee 3x3 basketball at the Olympics shares how her Muslim faith has guided her career.

item.title: Raye and Polydor split after claims record label wouldn't release debut album
item.description: The 23-year-old singer says she and Polydor have "different goals artistically".

item.title: Channel crossings migrants: 'We need a safe place'
item.description: A BBC team encounters some of the migrants trying to make the dangerous journey to England.

item.title: Covid: Vaccine passport plan for nightclubs 'concerning'
item.description: Manchester's night-time economy advisor brands the government's certification plan "discriminatory".

item.title: Covid: Can children have the Covid vaccine in the UK?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of under-18s will now be offered the jab in the UK - but not all. Here's why.

item.title: First space tourist Dennis Tito: 'I was euphoric'
item.description: Dennis Tito paid $20 million to travel to the International Space Station in 2001.

item.title: Can seaside town Scarborough's post-lockdown boom last?
item.description: The BBC's David Sillito visits his hometown of Scarborough, which is seeing a post-lockdown boom.

item.title: Tips for staying cool by people from hot countries
item.description: BBC colleagues from Nigeria, Tanzania, Yemen and Brazil give us their advice for coping with hot weather.

item.title: Covid is 'just the worst experience'
item.description: As most coronavrirus restrictions in England are lifted, Covid patients urge the public to take care.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Tom Daley on triumph, trauma and his likely last shot at gold
item.description: The 'baby' of Beijing has become a father, a husband and an LGBTQ+ spokesperson. Tom Daley has perhaps one final shot at Olympic gold.

item.title: Migrant crossings: What happens to migrants who reach the UK?
item.description: The government wants to cut the number of migrants crossing the Channel.

item.title: The little tech firm gunning for an airspeed record
item.description: Electroflight has built the E-NXT which it hopes will break the electric airspeed record.

item.title: Tony Blair's Irish Famine message not signed off by him, archive papers show
item.description: Files show the former PM's private secretary wrote the statement but could not reach him for approval.

item.title: How a football fan's collection of memorabilia is helping others
item.description: How a football fan's once-treasured collection is helping others to remember happier times.

item.title: Covid: Will lockdown change England's new tech habits?
item.description: The pandemic brought about big changes in the way people use tech - the question is will they last?

item.title: A weekend in America: Shootings in Washington spotlight growing problem
item.description: A stadium was sent into panic and a six-year-old was killed in two of the weekend's worst shootings.

item.title: Covid: Ivermectin, milk among Indonesia's unproven cures
item.description: As Indonesia sees a surge fuelled by the Delta variant, misleading health claims are spreading.

item.title: Dan Biggar: Grieving British and Irish Lions fly-half eyes Test start in South Africa
item.description: Dan Biggar targets an "emotional" first British and Irish Lions Test start against South Africa after the recent death of his mother.

item.title: Covid: What is the pilot testing scheme to avoid self-isolation?
item.description: The prime minister and chancellor were to participate in a trial to avoid self-isolation but then backtracked.

item.title: Joshua to fight Usyk at Tottenham's stadium in September
item.description: Anthony Joshua will defend his world heavyweight titles against Oleksandr Usyk at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium on 25 September.

item.title: All three Lions Tests to now be played in Cape Town
item.description: All three Tests between South Africa and the British and Irish Lions will now be staged in Cape Town because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Rescheduling Games 'caused sleepless nights', says IOC president
item.description: Rescheduling the Tokyo Olympics "caused sleepless nights" but must go ahead "to give hope" for the future, says IOC president Thomas Bach.

item.title: Premier League player arrested over child sex allegations
item.description: The Premier League player has since been bailed and suspended by his club while inquiries continue.

item.title: South Africa captain Kolisi to start against Lions after recovering from Covid-19
item.description: South Africa captain Siya Kolisi recovers from Covid-19 to be named in the starting XV to face the British and Irish Lions in the first Test on Saturday.

item.title: England Test players available for opening Hundred games
item.description: England men's Test players will be available for the first two rounds of The Hundred before the squad convenes for the series against India.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Duke of Cambridge meets Team GB boxer and medal hopeful Lauren Price
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge meets Team GB boxer and medal hopeful Lauren Price at Kensington Palace.

item.title: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: 'Covid passports': How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both jabs?
item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England will have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: New research links as many as 200 different symptoms to the condition.

item.title: Covid rules from 19 July: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: Rules on self-isolation are being eased in England for children and fully vaccinated adults.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but Boris Johnson has criticised the take-up among young people.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: The EU vaccine 'passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: An EU vaccine "passport" is being introduced, enabling holders to prove they have been jabbed.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Partner vows to keep searching for missing hiker
item.description: The partner of missing hiker Esther Dingley explains why he won't give up searching for her.

item.title: Under the skin of OnlyFans
item.description: A BBC investigation reveals concerns about how the site, known for porn, is structured and moderated.

item.title: The Broadway dancer whose lockdown business bloomed
item.description: When Covid closed New York theatres, dancer Robbie Fairchild started a business that put down roots.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Unvaccinated patients with many regrets
item.description: The number of Covid patients in Bradford Royal Infirmary is rising sharply - and half are unvaccinated.

item.title: Olympic Games: 'Gang life nearly killed me - sprinting was my way out'
item.description: As Darren Campbell emerged as a talented teenage sprinter, he was leading a double life as a gang member. A twist of fate broke him free.
